awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: A Neuroeconomic Analysis of Personality and Learning Strategic Games
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds a doctoral dissertation that combines methods from social psychology, cognitive neuroscience, and behavioral economics.  The coPI seeks to measure the neurobiology of personality traits, the adaptive properties of these traits in the context of strategic games, and the relation of these traits to experience-based learning and abstract reasoning.  In particular, the research investigates how the relative salience of potential gains and losses interact with specific personality traits to determine a decision-maker's success in using the relatively complicated mental process of backwards induction.

The project extends current research on the neural correlates of personality and choice-behavior to the domain of strategic decision making and abstract reasoning.  The project also provides a foundation for a formal description of personality traits as characteristic adaptive properties in the context of a strategic decision.  The coPI plans to formulate and test an empirical model of learning in strategic games that includes personality traits as an independent variable.

The broader impacts include training a graduate student in a wide variety of research methods that are important for interdisciplinary research in behavioral science.  The research may also prove useful in helping us understand how to improve the ways information is presented to individuals who carry out collective decision tasks.

por.por_cntn:
A central motivation for this dissertation project was to facilitate interdisciplinary investigation of human decision making by identifying and describing neurophysiological underpinnings of individual differences in personality, including cognitive ability (intelligence), and linking these to behavior. The main objective of the conducted experimental research was therefore to contribute towards an empirical basis from which to consolidate neural substrates of decision making into formal models capable of linking economic decision theory with psychological descriptions of mental information processing. One particularly important outcome of this project was the identification of a novel relation between intelligence and the experience of monetary reward and punishment (Hawes, et al. 2014). The identified relation constitutes important evidence that individual differences in preferences for risk and uncertainty - known to correlate with IQ (e.g. Burks, et al. 2009)- may be rooted in the way that probabilistic outcomes are experienced post choice, rather than being exclusively dependent on how probabilistic options are evaluated pre choice. The finding – within the limitations of a single experiment - helps establish a better understanding of the link between intelligence and preferences, by demonstrating that this link extends beyond the impact of cognitive ability on the efficiency with which decision options are compared, and with which choices are executed. Instead, the finding suggests that this link may be significantly rooted in a mechanistic influence of cognitive ability on actual preferences and experienced sensation following probabilistic reward/punishment.

A central observation in our data demonstrates that individuals who scored higher on standardized IQ tests showed attenuated neural responses to monetary losses during a simple reward/punishment learning task. We were able to link this observation conceptually to subjects’ behavior in our experimental task by further analyzing subjects’ responses to feedback during the experimental reward/punishment learning task used in our experiment. With respect to this behavior we found that subjects with higher scores on IQ tests – i.e. subjects identified as possessing greater general cognitive ability – responded to extended feedback episodes, and selected actions that appeared informed by events that occurred multiple periods back. In comparison, subjects with lower IQ scores seemed primarily influenced by recent feedback episodes and made choices in our task that were more myopically informed, and were best predicted by the most recently observed outcome of the previous choice.

Our experimental findings can be described within the framework of a mathematical model of reinforcement learning in which subjects with greater cognitive ability evaluate outcomes from unknown probabilistic processes against a larger number of candidate processes. A consequence for observed prediction errors derived from this description is an improved convergence to the true reward process for subjects with higher IQ. For the specific reward process chosen in our experiment an additional corollary is a reduced negative prediction error after losses, which we relate to the observed attenuated neural signal after losses.
